questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is mamillary body and the fibers from the mamillary body end in the anterior nucleus of the thalamus.

The mammillary bodies are two small hemispherical, pea-sized eminences, lying side by side, forming the floor of the third ventricle. The fibres from medial mammillary nucleus project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus.

The anterior thalamic nuclei have 3 subdivisions—anteroventral nucleus, anteromedial nucleus, and anterodorsal nucleus.

  • Major input: Mamillothalamic tract from the mammillary nuclei of the hypothalamus.
  • Major cortical output: Anterior limbic area, cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyrus 
  • Major function:
    • Regulation of alertness and attention
    • Acquisition of memory

 

Related Pearl: Thalamus and its connections

Nuclei Input Output Function
Anterior 

Mamillothalamic tract, cingulate gyrus, hypothalamus

 Cingulate gyrus, hypothalamus Regulation of alertness and attention, acquisition of memory
Dorsomedial

Prefrontal cortex, hypothalamus, other thalamic nuclei

 Prefrontal cortex, hypothalamus, other thalamic nuclei Integration of somatic, visceral, and olfactory information and relation to emotional feelings and subjective states
Lateral dorsal, lateral posterior and pulvinar Cerebral cortex and other thalamic nuclei  Cerebral cortex and other thalamic nuclei  Unknown
Ventral postero lateral

Medial lemniscus

spinothlamic pathway

 Primary somatosensory area cortex Relays common sensations to consciousness
Ventral posteromedial

Gustatory

Trigeminal

 Primary somatosensory area cortex Relays common sensations to consciousness
Ventral anterior Reticular formation, substantia nigra, corpus striatum, premotor cortex, other thalamic nuclei Reticular formation, substantia nigra, corpus striatum, premotor cortex, other thalamic nuclei Influences activity of motor cortex
Ventral lateral Cerebellum, reticular formation, substantia nigra, corpus striatum, premotor cortex, other thalamic nuclei Cerebellum, reticular formation, substantia nigra, corpus striatum, premotor cortex, other thalamic nuclei Influences activity of motor cortex
Intralaminar Reticular formation, spinothalamic and trigeminothalamic tracts To cerebral cortex via other thalamic nuclei and corpus striatum Influences level of consciousness and alertness
Midline Reticular formation Unknown Unknown
Reticular Cerebral cortex, reticular formation Other thalamic nuclei Cerebral cortex regulating thalamus
Medial geniculate body Inferior colliculus, lateral lemniscus from the predominantly opposite ear Auditory radiation to superior temporal gyrus Hearing
Lateral geniculate body Optic tract Optic radiation to the visual cortex of occipital lobe Visual information from the opposite field of vision

questions.text: During a clinical assessment, a neurologist stimulates a specific structure to evaluate the sensory supply from a cranial nerve. Which cranial nerve's sensory function is being assessed by touching the highlighted structure in the image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given sagittal section of the head and neck is the uvula. The sensory supply by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)  is tested in this case.

Innervation of the soft palate:

  • General sensation - Lesser palatine nerve(branch of maxillary nerve) and the pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve 
  • Taste sensation - Lesser palatine nerve.
  • Secretomotor supply -Lesser palatine nerve via postganglionic fibres from the pterygopalatine ganglion.
  • Motor supply - Pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve (except stylopharyngeus - supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve)

Pharyngeal plexus: The nerve supply of the pharynx is mainly from the pharyngeal plexus. The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and vagus nerve form it. (It also has contributions from the superior cervical ganglion) The vagus nerve provides the motor supply and the glossopharyngeal nerve provides the sensory supply.

Nerve supply by glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Sensory fibres to the uvula, tympanic cavity, pharyngotympanic tube, tonsils, fauces, nasopharynx, and posterior third of the tongue.
  • Motor fibres to the stylopharyngeus muscle
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland
  • Gustatory fibres for the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue.

Nerve supply by the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve:

  • All the muscles of the soft palate (except tensor veli palatini - supplied by mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve)
  • All the muscles of the pharynx(except stylopharyngeus - supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve)

questions.text: Identify the labelled structure in the image?
questions.solution:
The labelled structure contains the tectum, tegmentum and crus cerebri which are part of the midbrain.

The image given below shows the cross-section of the midbrain.

The midbrain develops from the midbrain vesicle, the cavity of which becomes much reduced to form the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius.

The midbrain is located in the posterior cranial fossa. It is surrounded by cerebrospinal fluid in the subarachnoid space. It has a cavity called the cerebral aqueduct, which opens above into the third ventricle.

questions.text: Identify the thickened nerve marked in the arrow in the image shown below:
questions.solution:
The thickened nerve marked with the arrow in the above image is the great auricular nerve and the thickened nerve visible below the great auricular nerve is the transverse cervical nerve.

Great auricular nerve:

It is the largest ascending branch of cervical plexus and arises from the second and the third cervical spinal nerves.

It winds over the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and ascends upwards. On reaching the parotid gland it divides into the anterior and posterior branches:

  • The anterior branch supplies the facial skin over the parotid gland and joins the facial nerve in the gland.
  • The posterior branch supplies the skin over mastoid process, lower part of back of the auricle, lobule and concha.

Clinical considerations:

The nerve can be thickened in conditions like leprosy and can be palpated over the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (as seen in the above image)

The great auricular nerve is the only nerve which is not a branch of trigeminal nerve and supplies the facial skin over the angle of mandible.

questions.text: The dermatome of the area marked in the given below image is__.
questions.solution:
The medial side of the leg and medial malleolus is supplied by the L4 dermatome.

Dermatome Area supplied
L1 Inguinal area (over inguinal canal)
L2 Anterior and lateral part of upper 2/3rd of thigh
L3 Anterior, lateral, medial parts of lower 1/3rd of thigh and knee
L4 Medial side of leg, medial malleolus
L5 Lateral side of leg, medial half of dorsum of foot, dorsum of first web space
S1 Posterior surface of ankle, lateral half of dorsum of foot
S2 Posterior surface of thigh and leg
S3 Gluteal area around perianal region, groin
S4 Perianal skin and groin

These dermatomes may vary considerably and overlap with each other. However, the overlap is minimal along the axial lines as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not pass through the foramen marked with the black arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The foramen marked in the image is the foramen ovale. The middle meningeal artery does not pass through the foramen ovale. It passes through the foramen spinosum.

The structures passing through the foramen ovale are:

  • Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve 
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins 

These structures can be remembered using the mnemonic 'MALE'.   

The structures passing through the foramen spinosum are:

  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus (meningeal branch of mandibular nerve)
  • Middle meningeal vein

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits
Optic canal
  • Optic nerves
  • Ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure
  • Lacrimal nerve (V1)
  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)
  • CNs III, IV, VI
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
Foramen rotundum
  • Maxillary division of CN V (V2)
Foramen ovale
  • Mandibular division of CN V (V3)
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins
Foramen spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein
Foramen lacerum
  • Deep petrosal nerve
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein
Carotid canal
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery
Jugular foramen
  • Inferior petrosal sinus
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • CNs IX,X & XI
  • Sigmoid Sinus continuing as IJV 
  • Middle meningeal branch of occipital artery
Hypoglossal canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
Foramen magnum
  • Osseo-ligamentous (anterior) compartment: 
    • Apical ligament and tip of dens
    • Upper band of cruciate ligament
    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: Which structure is supplied by the nerve causing this elevation?
questions.solution:
The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle and the facial colliculus which is an elevation caused by the facial nerve. Among the given options risorius is supplied by the facial nerve.

The fourth ventricle is located between the brainstem and the cerebellum. The rhomboid fossa is a diamond-shaped depression seen on the floor of the fourth ventricle. The superior and the inferior part of the floor is triangular in shape. It is divided by a longitudinal median sulcus into two halves. Each half is again divided into the medial and lateral regions.

The facial colliculus is present in the superior part, which presents as a small elevation produced by the root of the facial nerve winding around the nucleus of the abducens nerve.  Columns are formed by groups of facial neurones, which innervate individual muscles and give branches of the facial nerve. Dorsal neurones innervate muscles in the scalp and upper face and ventral neurons supply the lower facial musculature. 

Risorius falls under the buccolabial muscle group and act as the elevator, retractor and evertor of the upper lip. Some of its peripheral attachments are the zygomatic arch, parotid fascia and fascia over the mastoid process. It is involved in actions like grinning and laughing and is innervated by the buccal branches of the facial nerve.

Other options:

Option A: Lateral rectus is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring. It is innervated by the abducens nerve. 

Option B: Superior oblique is an extraocular muscle that arises from the body of the sphenoid. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve. 

Option D: Levator palpebrae superiors is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lesser wing of sphenoid. It is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. 

Related Pearl: Extraocular muscles and their actions

Muscle Primary action Secondary action Tertiary action
Superior rectus Elevation Intorsion Adduction
Inferior rectus Depression Extorsion Adduction
Medial rectus Adduction --- --- 
Lateral rectus Abduction ---- ---
Superior oblique Intorsion Depression Abduction
Inferior oblique Extorsion Elevation Abduction

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reaction, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
The above patient presents with features suggesting an involvement of the trigeminal nerve. The structure marked 3 is the trigeminal nerve.

Other marked structures:

  • 1- Optic nerve. The normal visual field and light reflex rules out the involvement of the optic nerve.
  • 2- Oculomotor nerve. Normal accommodation and pupillary reflex rule out the involvement of the oculomotor nerve.
  • 4- Facial nerve. Absence of motor involvement of the face rule out the involvement of the facial nerve.

The trigeminal nerve leaves the anterior aspect of the pons as a small motor root and a large sensory root. The large sensory root expands to form the crescent-shaped trigeminal ganglion, which lies within a pouch of dura mater called the trigeminal or Meckel's cave. The ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves arise from the anterior border of the ganglion.

Branches of the trigeminal nerve:

  • The ophthalmic nerve (V1)
    • Leaves the skull through the superior orbital fissure to enter the orbital cavity.
    • Contains only sensory fibers
      • Cornea (photophobia)
      • The skin of the forehead, scalp, eyelids, and nose
      • The mucous membrane of paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity
  • The maxillary nerve (V2)
    • Leaves the skull through the foramen rotundum.
    • Contains only sensory fibers from
      • Teeth of the upper jaw
      • The skin of the face over the maxilla
      • The mucous membrane of the nose, the maxillary sinus, and the palate
  • The mandibular nerve (V3)
    • Leaves the skull through the foramen ovale.
    • Contains both sensory and motor fibers.
    • Sensory from:
      • The skin of the cheek, over mandible, and side of the head
      • Teeth of the lower jaw and temporomandibular joint (hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth)
      • The mucous membrane of the mouth and anterior part of the tongue
    • Motor to:
      • Muscles of mastication (pterygoids, masseter, and temporalis)
      • Tensor tympani
      • Anterior belly of digastric
      • Mylohyoid

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the pterion. 

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  1. Frontal bone
  2. Squamous part of the temporal bone
  3. Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  4. Parietal bone

It is located approximately 4 cm above the midpoint of the zygomatic arch. 

 

Centre of pterion is referred to as sylvian point and the bone is thinnest at this point.

Frontal branch of middle meningeal artery, vein and lateral sulcus of brain are situated immediately below this point. Pterion is one of the commonest site of fracture and leads to extradural hemorrhage because of injury to middle meningeal artery.

The pterion overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin, and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery, leading to extradural hematoma.

The pterion also corresponds to the site of the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle of the neonatal skull, which closes in the third month after birth.

Other options:

Option A: Asterion is the point where three cranial bones meet:

  • the parietal bone.
  • the occipital bone.
  • the mastoid portion of the temporal bone.

It lies 4 cm behind and 12 mm above the center of the entrance to the ear canal.

Option B: The glabella is the area of skin between the eyebrows and above the nose, that is slightly depressed, and joins the two brow ridges. 

Option D: The nasion (also known as bridge of the nose) is the midline bony depression between the eyes where the frontal and two nasal bones meet, just below the glabella.

questions.text: A middle-aged female comes to the clinic for follow-up three weeks after left parotidectomy. She complains of flushing, sweating, and burning sensation on the left side of her face every time she sits down to have a meal. The postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of which of the following nerves is the likely culprit for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The symptom complex in this patient along with a history of recent parotid surgery is indicative of Frey's syndrome in which the auriculotemporal nerve marked as "D" is involved.

Frey’s syndrome/Gustatory sweating (auriculotemporal syndrome)

  • Commonly develops after parotid surgery or other trauma that results in the opening of the parotid capsule.
  • It results from damage to the autonomic innervation of the salivary gland. There is a regeneration of the parasympathetic nerve fibres that stimulate the sweat glands of the overlying skin in response to salivary stimulation or mastication. 
  • It is thought to reflect abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face by regrowing parasympathetic secretomotor axons that would previously have innervated the parotid gland
  • Clinical features:
    • Sweating, warmth, and erythema over the region of surgical excision of the parotid gland. This is due to the autonomic stimulation of salivation by the smell/taste of food.
  • Diagnosis:
    • The starch iodine will aid in diagnosis. The affected area painted with iodine will turn blue on exposure to sweat.
  • Management:
    • Antiperspirants with aluminium chloride
    • Subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area
    • Denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion has been advocated but is often not curative

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the Genioglossus muscle.

Genioglossus is one of the extrinsic muscles of the tongue which bring about the forward traction of the tongue to protrude its apex from the mouth. Hence, it is also called the safety muscle of the tongue.

Origin: The superior mental spine (also called the superior genial tubercle) of the mandible, located on the internal surface of the mandible near the symphysis (midline).
Insertion: The muscle fans out and inserts into the entire length of the inferior surface of the tongue and the body of the hyoid bone.

Acting bilaterally, the two muscles depress the central part of the tongue, making it concave from side to side. Acting unilaterally, the tongue diverges to the opposite side.

Other options:

Option B: Hyoglossus: depresses the tongue

Option C: Styloglossus: draws the tongue up and backward.

Option D: Palataglossus: elevate the posterior portion of the tongue

All muscles of tongue are derived from occipital myotomes, hence innervated by hypoglossal nerve, except palatoglossus which is derived from the pharyngeal arch and is supplied by vago-accessory nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve can be injured, when a fracture is sustained at the area marked with the red arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
In the given image the arrow points to the medial epicondyle. Fracture at the medial epicondyle damages the ulnar nerve. 

The nerves related to the humerus are:

  • Axillary nerve is at the surgical neck 
  • Ulnar nerve is at the medial epicondyle
  • Radial nerve is at the spiral groove of the shaft of the humerus. 

Ulnar nerve branches and supply: 

Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

Injury to the ulnar nerve can be as follows:

  High lesion
(Elbow) 		 Low lesion 
(Wrist) 
Site of injury
  • Fracture/dislocation of the medial epicondyle
  • Cubital tunnel syndrome
  • Compression between the two heads of FCU
  • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy (Valgus deformity)
  • Wrist laceration/ slashing
  • Guyon's canal syndrome
Motor loss
  • Claw-hand deformity
  • Hypothenar & interosseous wasting
  • Loss of:
    • Abduction & adduction of fingers
      (Card test - Positive)
    • Adduction of thumb
      (Froment sign- Positive)
    • Flexion of MCP joints
  • Weakness of wrist flexion (radial deviation)
  • Claw-hand deformity
    (more pronounced)
  • Hypothenar & interosseous wasting
  • Loss of:
    • Abduction & adduction of fingers
      (Card test - Positive)
    • Adduction of thumb
      (Froment sign- Positive)
Sensory loss
  • Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial third of the hand
  • Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial 1 1/2 fingers
  • No sensory loss over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial third of the hand
  • Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial 1 1/2 fingers

Other tests seen in ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:

  • Claw hand deformity
  • Froment's sign positive
  • Wartenberg sign
  • Palmaris brevis sign

The image below shows a positive card test:

Wartenberg's sign: (Weakness of palmar interossei), Sensory loss of palmar and dorsal surface of the medial third of hand and medial 1 and a half fingers.

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured

Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve

Volkman’s ischemic contracture Anterior interosseous nerve
Hook of hamate fracture Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Lunate dislocation  Median nerve
Wrist injury Median nerve
Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve
Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)

Related Pearl: Injuries around the elbow

  • Fracture of medial epicondyle of humerus

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the superior oblique muscle. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

This is a recent AIIMS question. The anatomy of extraocular muscles is a high yield topic and is repeated tested in all the exams.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked. 

There are four lumbrical muscles. They originate from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. It passes to the radial side of the corresponding fingers and is inserted into the dorsal digital expansion of the extensor digitorum.

The action of lumbricals is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joint and extension of interphalangeal joints. 

Lumbricals can be tested only along with interosseous muscle. The examiner will hold the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger in hyperextension. Then the patient is asked to extend the proximal interphalangeal joint against resistance. The test is repeated on other fingers as well.

The median nerve innervates the first and second lumbricals. The deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the third and the fourth. 

The median nerve is formed by the union of the lateral root (C6, 7) from the lateral cord, and the medial root (C8, T1) from the medial cord.

On the hand, it is seen proximal to the flexor retinaculum and lateral to the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis. It also lies between the tendons of flexor carpi radialis and palmaris longus.

Its cutaneous supply in hand is as follows: 

  • Lateral 2/3rd of the palm by superficial cutaneous branch
  • Lateral 3½ fingers (palmar aspect and dorsal aspect of nailbeds) by palmar digital nerves

The muscles supplied by the median nerve in the hand are flexor pollicis brevis, abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and first dorsal interosseous.

The median nerve sometimes gets compressed under the fibro-osseous tunnel beneath the flexor retinaculum leading to carpal tunnel syndrome. 

Pen test is used to test the median nerve in the hand. It tests the abductor pollicis brevis muscle.  The hand must remain flat with the palm facing upwards. A pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb.

questions.text: Third part of vertebral artery is related to which of the following ?
questions.solution:
The third part of the vertebral artery (V3) is related to the area marked 2, which is the posterior arch of the first cervical vertebra or the atlas.

The given image shows the first cervical vertebra - atlas.

  • The area marked 1 is the posterior tubercle.
  • The area marked 2 is the posterior arch. The superior surface bears a groove for the of vertebral artery and venous plexus immediately behind.
  • The area marked 3 is the superior articular facet.
  • The area marked 4 is the posterior surface of the anterior arch. It gives attachment to the apex of dens from the second cervical vertebra. 

The vertebral artery arises from the first part of the subclavian artery. It passes through the foramina of transverse processes of C6 to C1 cervical vertebrae and enters the cranium through the foramen magnum. The vertebral arteries of both sides join to form the basilar artery. In its course, it is divided into four parts:

The first part, V1, begins at its origin from the subclavian artery and ends at its entry into the transverse process of the C6 cervical vertebra. This part is crossed by the inferior thyroid artery on both sides, and thoracic duct on the left side, and the right lymphatic duct on the right side. 

The second part, V2 is that part of the artery ascending through the foramina in the transverse process of the cervical vertebrae. 

The third part, V3 is curved backward behind the atlas. In this position, it lies in a groove on the posterior arch of the atlas. This part of the artery lies in the suboccipital triangle. 

The fourth part, V4 pierces the dura and arachnoid mater and unites with the contralateral vertebral artery to form the midline basilar artery at the lower border of pons.

questions.text: Identify the tendon marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The tendon marked in the image is of Flexor carpi radialis.

Flexor carpi radialis:

  • Flexor carpi radialis arises from the medial epicondyle and its fusiform muscular belly converges in the mid-forearm into a long tendon.This tendon now passes within a synovial sheath through a lateral canal, formed by the flexor retinaculum above and a groove on the trapezium below.
  • It inserts on the palmar surface of the base of the second metacarpal and sends a slip to the third metacarpal.
  • Blood supply is by a branch that arises from either the anterior or the posterior ulnar recurrent artery. The distal minor pedicles supplying flexor carpi radialis are six to eight branches from the radial artery that enter the muscle on the anterolateral side.
  • It is innervated by the median nerve, root value is C6, C7.
  • It is a wrist flexor and acts with flexor carpi ulnaris for wrist flexion, and with the radial extensors of the wrist to abduct the hand.
  • Testing is by palpating its contracting fibers during flexion of the wrist against resistance.

questions.text: Identify the type of muscle marked as A in the image below.
questions.solution:
The muscle depicted in the diagram is the Pectoralis major, which is a spiral muscle.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

 

Quadrilateral: Thyrohyoid

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, Trapezius

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator

Strap like: Sartorius, Sternohyoid

Unipennate: Extensor digitorum longus, Flexor pollicis longus, Peroneus tertius, Palmar interossei

Partially cruciate and partially spiral: Masseter, Adductor magnus, Sternoclediomastoid 

Strap like with tendinous intersections: Rectus abdominis

Bipennate: Rectus femoris, Flexor hallucis longus, Peroneus longus, Dorsal interossei

 

Fusiform: Biceps brachii, digastric

Multipennate: Deltoid, Subscapularis

  

 

Circumpennate: Tibialis anterior

questions.text: A boy with a history of a fall from a tree presents with a lurching gait and dragging of his feet. Which of the following structures are involved?
questions.solution:
The structure responsible for lurching gait in the child is gluteus medius represented by 2.

The gluteus medius originates from the outer surface of the ileum between the anterior and posterior gluteal lines. Insertion of the muscle is at the lateral surface of the greater trochanter. It is supplied by the superior gluteal nerve.

Gluteus medius and minimus are powerful abductors of the hip joint. Mechanism of actions of gluteus medius and minimus:

  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in a slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • The actions of these muscles are affected when there is an injury to the superior gluteal nerve, neck of the femur, or loss of normal angulation of the shaft of the femur. This occurs in conditions like paralysis of the glutei, developmental dysplasia of the hip, etc.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb. This leads to a positive Trendelenburg's sign with a characteristic lurching gait - the patient lurches towards the affected side with contralateral pelvis drop. 

Other options

1 - Gluteus maximus - involved in the extension of flexed thigh, abduction (only upper fibres), and lateral rotation at the hip joint. Insertion is at the iliotibial tract. 

3 - Piriformis - involved in lateral rotation and assists abduction at the hip joint. It is inserted into the medial side of greater trochanter of the femur. Entrapment of the sciatic nerve in the piriformis can lead to piriformis syndrome.

4 - Sciatic nerve - The nerve passes over the obturator internus, gemellus superior, gemellus inferior and quadratus femoris. It supplies knee flexors and muscles below the knee. Paralysis of this nerve results in flail foot and severe difficulty in walking. 

Related Pearl: Muscles causing the movements at Hip joint

Movements Principal muscles involved in the movements
Flexion

Psoas major

Iliacus

Rectus femoris
Extension

Gluteus maximus

Biceps femoris

Semitendinosus

Semimembranosus (hamstrings)

Adductor magnus 
Abduction

Gluteus medius

Gluteus minimus

Assisted by tensor fascia lata, piriformis and sartorius.
Adduction

Gracilis.

Gluteus minimus

Tensor Fascia Lata

Adductor muscles.

questions.text: Identify the bony prominence marked in the image below
questions.solution:
The bone depicted in the above image is the Femur and the bony prominence marked "A" is the lesser trochanter.

The image below shows attachments of various muscles over the posterior surface of the right femur.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is being palpated in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the physician's fingertips between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon, and the artery being palpated here is the posterior tibial artery.

The posterior tibial artery can be felt by keeping the foot relaxed between plantar and dorsiflexion and palpating against the distal tibia behind and below the medial malleolus.

Other options:

Dorsalis pedis artery: 

  • Palpated against the underlying tarsals
  • It is palpated on the dorsum of the foot in the first intermetatarsal space just lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon.

Popliteal artery: 

  • Most difficult of the peripheral pulses to feel because the artery lies deep in the popliteal fossa.
  • Examined with the subject lying supine or prone, with the knee flexed in order to relax the tense popliteal fascia that roofs the popliteal fossa.
  • Felt over the midline of the fossa by deep pressure against the popliteal surface of the femur. 

Anterior Tibial Artery -

  • Anteriorly midway between the medial and lateral malleoli, lateral to the EHL tendon, against the lower end of the tibia

Arteries of the lower limb are:

questions.text: Given below is a dissected compartment of the leg. The nerve supplying these muscles does not give articular branches to?
questions.solution:
The given muscle is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve. It does not give articular branches to the 2nd metatarsophalangeal joint. 

The above image shows the anterior compartment of the leg. The deep peroneal nerve is the nerve of the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. It is one of the two terminal branches of the common peroneal nerve arising between the neck of the fibula and peroneus longus. It accompanies the anterior tibial artery. 

The deep peroneal nerve gives articular branches to-

  • Ankle joint
  • Tarsal joints
  • Tarsometatarsal joints
  • 1st metatarsophalangeal joint

Muscular branches-

  • Tibialis anterior 
  • Extensor hallucis longus 
  • Extensor digitorium  longus
  • Peroneus tertius 
  • Extensor digitorium brevis 

The 2nd metatarsophalangeal joint is supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

 

Related Pearl: Various muscles of the leg and their innervation:

 

Muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg and dorsum of foot

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the deep inguinal ring, which is formed by a defect in fascia transversalis.

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis. An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

It extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.

Boundaries:

Boundary

 Structures forming

Anterior wall
  • Skin, superficial fascia, external oblique aponeurosis (whole extent)
  • Muscle fibers of internal oblique (lateral 1/3rd)

Posterior wall
  • Parietal peritoneum, extraperitoneal tissues, fascia transversalis (whole extent)
  • Medially reinforced by the conjoint tendon and reflected part of the inguinal ligament

Roof
  • Arched fibers of internal oblique and transversus abdominis forming the conjoint tendon medially

Floor
  • Grooved surface of the inguinal ligament
  • Lacunar ligament at the medial end
 

Deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above the mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring is a triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest (or medial to the pubic tubercle).

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord contents

Inguinal canal contents:

Male Female
  • Spermatic cord  (with genital branch of genitofemoral nerve)
  • Ilioinguinal nerve
  • Round ligament of the uterus 
  • Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Ilioinguinal nerve

Spermatic cord contents:

  • Three arteries:
    • Testicular artery
    • Deferential artery
    • Cremasteric artery
  • Two nerves:
    • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
    • Sympathetic nerve fibers
  • Three other structures:
    • Ductus deferens
    • Pampiniform plexus of veins
    • Lymphatic vessels

questions.text: Injury at which of the following marked sites causes failure of dorsiflexion?
questions.solution:
The site marked as '3' in the x-ray given above is the neck of the fibula. Injury at this site causes failure of dorsiflexion (foot drop) due to injury to the common fibular nerve. 

It runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular head. It then curves laterally around the neck of the fibula and gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves.

  Superficial fibular nerve Deep fibular nerve
Motor innervation
  • Peroneus longus
  • Peroneus brevis
  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Tibialis anterior
  • Peroneus tertius
Sensory innervation
  • Lateral aspect of the lower leg
  • Dorsum of the toes except for the lateral side of the 5th toe and the first interdigital web-space

 
  • The first interdigital space
 

 

Injury to the common peroneal nerve at the level of the neck of the fibula causes foot drop. Ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion of the foot are lost, while the inversion and plantar flexion are usually preserved. Sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot, including the first web space, is lost. The ankle reflex is usually preserved.

questions.text: The structure marked in the image drains into:

choices.text: Junction of superior vena cava and left brachiocephalic veins
Junction of left jugular and left subclavian veins

questions.solution:
The image shows the thoracic duct which drains into the junction of the left jugular and left subclavian veins.

Thoracic duct begins in the abdomen at T-12 vertebral level as the continuation of cisterna chyli.

  • It is usually beaded due to its numerous valves.
  • It drains the body below the diaphragm (lower limbs, pelvis, abdomen) and left half of the body above the diaphragm (thorax, upper limb, head and neck).
  • Thoracic duct passes through the aortic hiatus in the diaphragm and ascends through the posterior mediastinum between the aorta and the azygous vein.
  • At T-5 level, it deviates to the left side and ascends to pass the thoracic inlet.

Tributaries of the thoracic duct:

  • Bilateral (right and left) descending thoracic lymph trunks which convey lymph from lower intercostal spaces (6 – 11).
  • Left upper intercostal lymph trunks, which convey lymph from the upper intercostal spaces (1-5).
  • Mediastinal lymph trunks
  • Left subclavian lymph trunk
  • Left jugular lymph trunk
  • Left bronchomediastinal lymph trunk

The lymph passes through larger lymphatics and eventually collect into two large trunks, the thoracic duct and right lymphatic duct, which in turn drain into the brachiocephalic veins.

  • Thoracic duct- drains both lower limbs, left upper limb, abdomen, left halves of thorax, and left side of the head and neck regions (areas shaded green in the image).
  • Right lymphatic duct- drains right upper limb, and right halves of thorax, and right side of the head and neck regions (areas shaded blue in the image).

questions.text: Which of the following structures develops from the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the allantois. Its distal portion forms the urachus, which in turn gives rise to the median umbilical ligament.

The given image shows an embryo at the end of the third week.

Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum arising from anti-mesenteric border of the ileum. It is a remnant of the proximal part of the vitelline duct, which is made up of pluripotent cell lining. Meckel's diverticulum may harbour abnormal tissues, containing embryonic remnants of other tissue types, mostly gastric mucosa.

Related Pearl: Remnants of Various Embryonic Parts of the Cardiovascular System

Embryonic part

Remnants

Ductus arteriosus

Ligamentum arteriosum

Umbilical artery

Proximal part: Superior vesical artery; Distal part: Medial umbilical ligament

Umbilical vein (left)

Ligamentum teres

Ductus venosus

Ligamentum venosum

Septum primum

Floor of fossa ovalis

Septum secundum

Lower free edge: Annulus ovalis

 curved upper Margin: limbus fossa ovalis

questions.text: The Para-sagittal section of the abdomen is given below. What is the superior border of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is epiploic foramen. The superior border of the epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow) is formed by the caudate lobe of the liver. 

Epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac. The pearl summarizes the various relations of the foramen.

The image attached shows the various peritoneal reflections.

 

Clinical note: Pringle maneuver (as shown below) is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.

Related Pearl: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

Relations of epiploic foramen:

Anterior
  • Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Posterior
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Body of T12 vertebra

Superior
  • Caudate lobe of the liver

Inferior
  • 1st part of duodenum

 

Relations of lesser sac:

Anterior
  • Caudate lobe of liver
  • Lesser omentum
  • Stomach
  • First 2 layers of the greater omentum

Posterior

Structures forming the stomach bed:

  • Pancreas
  • Splenic artery
  • Left kidney and suprarenal gland
  • Commencement of abdominal aorta and coeliac artery
  • Left crus of the diaphragm
  • Splenic flexure of the colon
  • Transverse mesocolon

Superior
  • Reflection of the peritoneum from the esophagus to the diaphragm

Inferior
  • Continuation of 2nd and 3rd layers of the greater omentum

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: 

  • The skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus is supplied by T7-T9.
  • The skin around the umbilicus is supplied by T10.
  • The skin below the umbilicus until the suprapubic region is supplied by T11, T12. 
  • The skin around genitalia and upper medial thigh is supplied by L1.

questions.text: Identify the angle shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The angle shown in the image is the costovertebral angle, formed between the lower border of the 12th rib and the vertebral column. 

Causes for pain/tenderness at the costovertebral angle include:

  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) - caused by Hantavirus.

 

The boundaries of renal angle are formed by the lower border of 12th rib and lateral border of the erector spinae muscle.

The lower pole of the kidney occupies this angle. Tenderness in this angle is usually suggestive of infection in and around the kidney or renal stones.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a cyanotic newborn, the echocardiogram shows pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. Defective maturation of which of the following labelled structures would cause this condition?
questions.solution:
This newborn is found to have pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. The structure which gives rise to the root of the pulmonary artery is the truncus arteriosus which is marked as '4' in the given image.

Structures marked:

  1. Sinus venosus
  2. Atrium
  3. Bulbus cordis
  4. Truncus arteriosus

The heart tube begins to bend by day 23. This bending creates the cardiac loop which is completed by day 28. The fate of various structures formed as a result of this bending is as follows:

Given below are the heart tube and their derivatives:

 Part of the heart tube Derivative structure in the heart

Bulbus cordis

  • Proximal 1/3 

 

  • Middle 1/3 (conus cordis)

 

  • Distal 1/3 (truncus arteriosus)

 

  • Trabeculated part of right ventricle

 

  • Outflow tract of right and left ventricles

 

  • Root and proximal portions of aorta and pulmonary artery
Primitive ventricle
  • Trabeculated part of the left ventricle
Primitive atrium
  • The common atrium that splits to right and left atrium

questions.text: The marked structure develops from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the azygos vein, which develops from the supracardinal vein.

The azygos system of veins forms a connecting channel between the superior and inferior venae cavae. It occupies the upper part of the posterior abdominal wall and the posterior mediastinum. It also connects the portal, caval system, and vertebral venous systems. It drains the thoracic wall and the upper lumbar region.

Development: The azygos venous system arises from the supra cardinal veins. The right supra cardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while the left supra cardinal vein becomes the hemiazygos vein.

  • The 4th to 11th right intercostal veins empty into the right supracardinal vein, which together with a portion of the posterior cardinal vein forms the azygos vein.
  • The 4th to 7th left intercostal veins empty into the left supracardinal vein, and the left supracardinal vein continues as the hemiazygos vein, which also empties into the azygos vein.

Other options: Cardinal veins form the main venous drainage system of the embryo. It consists of,

  • Anterior cardinal veins, which drain the cephalic part of the embryo, and
  • Posterior cardinal veins, which drain the rest of the embryo.

During the fifth to the seventh weeks, a number of additional veins are formed. It includes,

  • Subcardinal veins, which mainly drain the kidneys;
  • Sacrocardinal veins, which drain the lower extremities;
  • Supracardinal veins, which drain the body wall by way of the intercostal veins.

The below image shows the development of cardinal veins
